list.item: Aug 2019 - extensive additions, entire collection reprocessed to integrate (SM, PRB, MS, MRC)

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.abstract: Papers of the Hungarian-American psychiatrist and scholar. Collection contains correspondence, memorabilia, photographs, writings, audio and video recordings.
did.langmaterial: Majority in English, some items in Hungarian, French, German, Japanese and Spanish.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Thomas Szasz (1920-2012) was an American psychiatrist and scholar, best known for his criticisms of psychiatry and of the influence of modern medicine on society, as well as the intersection of law and psychiatry.

Born in Budapest, Hungary, April 15 1920, Thomas Stephen Szasz emigrated to the United States in 1938. He received his medical education at the University of Cincinnati and his psychiatric training at the University of Chicago Clinics. In 1956 he became Professor of Psychiatry at the State University of New York, Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse, New York, a post he held until 1990 when he became Professor Emeritus. He was a well-known social critic of the moral and scientific foundations of psychiatry, and of the social control aims of medicine in modern society, as well as of scientism. A libertarian, Szasz advocated for the legalization of all drugs, the abolition of involuntary incarceration, and "the right to be mentally ill." Szasz was a prolific author with strong opinions on the relationship between modern psychiatry and the state, and his writings often evoked lively debate and conversations. His books include
The Myth of Mental Illness (1960) and
The Manufacture of Madness: A Comparative Study of the Inquisition and the Mental Health Movement (1970).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p:
The
Thomas Szasz Papers consist of biographical material, correspondence, financial material, memorabilia, subject files, writings by Szasz and by others, and media.
Biographical material contains biographical and autobiographical sketches, both published (e.g., in Who's Who in America) and unpublished.

Correspondence-subject files contains both incoming and (because Szasz regularly retained carbons of his letters) outgoing correspondence. A small amount of family correspondence is filed first, including his parents, brother George, and daughters Margot and Suzy. The vast majority of the correspondence is with readers, editors, publishers, medical colleagues (physicians, psychiatrists, psychologists), lawyers, medical journals, and others with whom he interacted professionally. Individuals and organizations of note include Melvin Belli, Burton Blatt, William F. Buckley, the Church of Scientology (in both the United States and other countries), Timothy Leary, the New York Times, and Karl Popper. Many of the correspondents also appear in the Subject files and in the Writings by others series; the researcher is encouraged to review the full finding aid thoroughly to ensure locating all relevant material.
Financial material consists almost entirely of royalty statements from American and foreign publishers. There are a few folders of bills and financial settlements.

Memorabilia contains awards, personal documentation relating to military service and naturalization as a US citizen, photographs, printed material about Szasz (clippings, reprints, journal articles), scrapbooks, and travel receipts and souvenirs.

Recordings contains audio and video recordings, some commercial but most home-made. Included here are recordings of Szasz speaking at conferences, appearing on radio or television programs, being interviewed, delivering lectures, and so on. Others who appear include Elie Wiesel, Jacqui Rutten, Ralph Slovenko, and more. There are also a few transcribed telephone calls and some commercially-produced and sold items.

As part of his approach to research and writing, Szasz maintained extensive
Subject files on people, events, ideas, and topics pertinent to his work. Folder titles in this series are, wherever possible, Szasz's own titles taken either from the folder itself or from his handwritten annotation on items within a folder. Topics range from AIDS, cartoons, and faith healing to John Hinckley Jr., the Tylenol cyanide tampering scare, and witchcraft.

Writings by Szasz are subdivided into articles, books, book chapters, interviews, introductions, letters to the editor, reviews, speeches, and miscellaneous items. In many cases -- with the books in particular -- there are numerous drafts with major or minor edits.

Writings by others includes drafts, typescripts, advance reading copies, and bound (but not published) articles, essays, papers, books, book chapters, and so on. In many cases the authors were requesting Szasz's thoughts or input on their work, or were expressing their gratitude for his influence on their thinking. One unusual item is the three folders of humorous skits written (and presumably performed) by Szasz's interns and residents which parody or make fun of Szasz and other notable psychiatrists. Also in this series are the drafts of Living With It, an autobiography/memoir by Szasz's daughter Suzy.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent; a small amount of family correspondence is filed first. All other series are arranged alphabetically by type of material and/or by title of item. Within Memorabilia, clippings about Szasz and travel receipts are arranged chronologically.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: A number of books that were donated as part of the collection have been transferred to Rare Books for cataloging. Please refer to &summitref; and search for "Gift of Thomas Szasz" to locate these items.
Approximately 9 linear feet of material has been removed from the collection due to issues of medical and legal privacy.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The majority of our archival and manuscript collections are housed offsite and require advanced notice for retrieval. Researchers are encouraged to contact us in advance concerning the collection material they wish to access for their research.
Access to recordings requires advance notice to produce a use copy.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Written permission must be obtained from SCRC and all relevant rights holders before publishing quotations, excerpts or images from any materials in this collection.
Regarding legal files and case studies: No personal names are to be published without the written permission of both Dr. Szasz and the named individual(s).

did.abstract: Szasz's parents, children, other relatives; much of the early material is in Hungarian
Szasz's oldest daughter, her husband, and son

scopecontent.p: George has difficult handwriting. Letters are often signed just "G" that can look like a "C." A number of the folders contain correspondence to/from others (usually referencing Thomas) including a plethora of letters from "Ursula" (often typed in German, sometimes individual letters and sometimes typed/written on the back of George's).

"Atya" is a Hungarian term for "father" so those letters have been filed here. There is some discussion in other letters between Thomas and George addressed to "Anya" (Hungarian term for "mother") about a dispute regarding who has rights to Atya's papers/writings.

did.unittitle: "Ehre den vergessern Opfern" bronze plaque rubbing

scopecontent.p: Handmade rubbing of a bronze plaque commemorating the 200,000 victims of "Aktion T4," Germany's program of euthanasia for those deemed mentally or physically "unworthy." Those involved in carrying out the program included "scientists, doctors, nurses, policemen and law, health and work officials." The original is embedded in the ground near Robert Serra's "Berlin Junction" sculpture in Tiergartenstrasse in Berlin.

I've purchased several copies because I wanted my friends and colleagues to be aware of it and make of it what they will. If you would like to keep the tape please compensate me the $10 I paid for it. Dan Klein."

Szasz maintained his own research files on a wide range of topics. The listing below gives Szasz's original title, as it was written on the folder or on the material inside. For material without a title, one was assigned based on the material; these titles are given in square brackets [ ] to distinguish from Szasz's own. Types of material vary widely and include photocopies, reprints, clippings, retyped/edited news articles, handwritten notes, typed pages of quotations, programs/brochures, and more.

scopecontent.p: Interviews of Szasz published (unless otherwise indicated) in popular magazines, newspapers, and professional journals, and on radio/television programs. Most are American but German, French, and other foreign media are also represented. Interviews for unidentified purpose/publication are filed at the end, alphabetized by name of interviewer.

scopecontent.p: Szasz was a frequent writer of letters to the editors of newspapers (New York Times, Washington Post),magazines (The Economist, National Review), and professional journals (American Journal of Psychiatry , The Lancet). In many cases these files also include clippings and letters he received from the editors or readers in response.

scopecontent.p: Included here are reviews written by Szasz of books by others. They are published, unless otherwise indicated. Most are reviews of non-fiction books and policy papers, but there are a few of novels, television shows, and other forms of popular culture. The original folders have Szasz's reference numbers on them; these have been clipped and filed inside the new folders.

scopecontent.p: O'Connor v. Donaldson (1975) was a landmark court case, in which the U.S. Supreme Court held that a finding of "mental illness" alone cannot justify confinement of a non-dangerous person against their will. Szasz gave a three-day series of talks on this topic, as the 1975-1976 Robert S. Marx Lectures at the University of Cincinnati Law School. The first folder includes the list of lecture/section topics and a copy of "Candid Campus," the University of Cincinnati student newspaper, with the announcement about Szasz.

scopecontent.p: This series includes drafts, typescripts, advance reading copies, etc. of articles, essays, papers, books, book chapters, and so on. There are also three folders of humorous skits written and performed by SUNY Upstate psychiatry students in residency. Some have annotations, revisions, comments, or edits by Szasz. If the item was eventually published, publication date is given in parentheses following the title.
